title: Make area names clickable with property listing navigation

requirements.summary: Convert area names in Featured Properties section into clickable links that navigate to filtered property listings for the selected area
acceptanceCriteria: Area names in property cards are rendered as clickable links or buttons
Clicking an area name navigates to a filtered view showing only properties in that area
Navigation works on both desktop and mobile devices

file_operations.description: Convert area name text (e.g., 'Gulshan', 'Banani', 'Dhanmondi') into clickable links that navigate to area-specific filtered property views. Use React Router Link component or programmatic navigation with onClick handlers. Ensure the link wraps only the area name portion of the location text while maintaining the existing layout and styling.

requirements.summary: Create dynamic area landing page with URL routing support for filtered property listings by area name
acceptanceCriteria: A dedicated route or section exists for each area (e.g., /properties/gulshan or #gulshan)
The area landing page displays all properties matching that area
URL is bookmarkable and shareable for direct access to area-specific listings
Navigation is clear and users can easily return to the main property listing view

file_operations.description: Create a new page component that displays filtered property listings based on the area parameter from the URL. Include a header showing the area name, a back/breadcrumb navigation to return to main view, and a grid of property cards filtered by the selected area. Handle case-insensitive area matching and display appropriate messaging when no properties match the area filter.

Wire the PropertyListingPage into the application routing structure. Import BrowserRouter, Routes, and Route from react-router-dom. Wrap the existing App content in a Routes structure with a root route that displays all existing sections, and add a dynamic route for /properties/:area that renders the PropertyListingPage component. Ensure smooth transitions between views.

requirements.summary: Style clickable area name links with clear visual indicators using navy blue or gold from STATEGURD brand palette, with hover underline and sufficient contrast
acceptanceCriteria: Area name links use navy blue or gold color from the existing brand palette
Links display an underline on hover state
Links have sufficient color contrast for accessibility
Visual styling is consistent across desktop and mobile views

file_operations.description: Apply styling to area name links using Tailwind CSS classes. Use text-navy or text-gold from the existing color palette, add hover:underline for hover state, ensure cursor-pointer is applied, and include transition-all duration-200 for smooth hover effects. Verify sufficient color contrast ratios meet WCAG AA standards for accessibility. Maintain consistent styling across all viewport sizes.

Style the back navigation link and area header using the same navy blue or gold color scheme with hover effects. Ensure the breadcrumb or back button follows STATEGURD brand guidelines with proper spacing and visual hierarchy.

requirements.summary: Implement smooth scroll behavior or page transitions when navigating between main view and area-specific filtered views
acceptanceCriteria: Navigation to area-specific views includes smooth scroll or fade transition animation
Transition duration is between 300-600ms for optimal UX
Transitions work consistently on both desktop and mobile devices

file_operations.description: Add CSS rules for smooth scroll behavior on the html element and define fade-in animation keyframes for page transitions. Set scroll-behavior: smooth globally and create animation classes that can be applied to route transitions with 300-600ms duration.

Implement route transition animations using CSS classes or React transition libraries. Apply fade-in animations when PropertyListingPage mounts and ensure scroll position resets to top on route changes. Add a useEffect hook that scrolls to top smoothly when the route changes to an area-specific view.
